title: How to Make Pour Over Coffee

steps.title: Set up your pour over brewer and get out the coffee.
steps.content: Set up your pour over brewer and get out the coffee. Place the pour over brewer of your choice over a carafe. Get out a digital scale and measure out 3 tablespoons (about 30 g) of medium-ground coffee or whole beans, if you want to grind your own. [1] X Research source You can use a glass, plastic, or ceramic brewer. Keep in mind that plastic brewers can give a slight taste to the coffee. You'll also need a grinder, if you plan to grind your own beans.

steps.title: Bring fresh water to boil.
steps.content: Bring fresh water to boil. Pour at least 17 ounces (500 g or ml) of water into a kettle and heat it until it boils vigorously. You can use tap or filtered water, depending on your preferences. Remove the kettle from the heat and let the water cool for about 30 seconds before you start the pour over. The temperature of the water should be around 205 °F (96 °C). To make it easier to pour, consider using a kettle with a long, narrow pouring spout.

steps.title: Put the filter into the brewer.
steps.content: Put the filter into the brewer. Use a filter designed for your specific pour over. If you're using one shaped like a cone, you'll need to fold the filter along the flat bottom and the edge with the seam. Set the filter into the brewer and place it on your carafe. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the filter.
steps.content: Rinse the filter. Pour enough hot water into the filter to wet it. The entire paper filter should be moist. Rinsing the filter will remove any papery residue so your coffee doesn't have a woodsy taste. [3] X Research source The moistened filter will also seal the filter against the brewer while warming up the carafe.

steps.title: Discard the rinse water and set the brewer on the carafe.
steps.content: Discard the rinse water and set the brewer on the carafe. Avoid using the rinse water in the bottom of the carafe. Lift up the brewer and pour out the water. Then set the brewer with the wet filter back on the carafe. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Grind the coffee, if you're using whole beans.
steps.content: Grind the coffee, if you're using whole beans. You'll get the best flavor of coffee by grinding whole beans just before brewing. Measure out 30 g of whole beans and place them in your grinder. Grind the beans until they're medium-fine which is about the size of coarse sugar. [5] X Research source Burr grinders will give you more control over the grind and will make more uniform grounds than blade grinders will.

steps.title: Put the coffee in the filter and set the pour over on a digital scale.
steps.content: Put the coffee in the filter and set the pour over on a digital scale. Measure 3 tablespoons (about 30 g) of coffee grounds into the moistened filter. Shake the brewer a little so the coffee grounds are at an even level. Level grounds will make the coffee extract evenly. Then place the carafe with the brewer on a digital scale and set it to zero. [6] X Research source You'll need to keep track of how much water you're pouring over the grounds, so the scale comes in handy.

steps.title: Start the timer and pour enough water to saturate the grounds.
steps.content: Start the timer and pour enough water to saturate the grounds. Start your digital timer so you can keep track of how long to brew the coffee. Take the kettle of hot water and slowly pour water in a circular motion over the coffee grounds in the filter. Pour just enough water to soak the grounds, but not so much that water begins to drip out of the bottom of the filter. [7] X Research source You should see the coffee bloom. This bubbling is the carbon dioxide releasing from the beans.

steps.title: Wait 30 to 45 seconds.
steps.content: Wait 30 to 45 seconds. Let the coffee grounds finish releasing gas so water can replace the carbon dioxide during the brewing process. Keep the timer going during the entire brewing process, which should take 3 to 4 minutes total.

steps.title: Pour hot water into the coffee grounds and wait 30 seconds.
steps.content: Pour hot water into the coffee grounds and wait 30 seconds. Slowly pour hot water into the grounds in a spiral movement. Take about 15 seconds to pour enough water to fill the brewer 1/2 to 3/4 full. Then wait 30 seconds while the coffee brews into the carafe below it. [8] X Research source Avoid pouring onto the filter because you'll get the best taste by saturating the coffee grounds.

steps.title: Pour again and wait another 45 to 65 seconds.
steps.content: Pour again and wait another 45 to 65 seconds. Slowly pour hot water into the center of the grounds and move towards the edges in a spiral motion. Fill the brewer 1/2 to 3/4 full again and then let the coffee brew for 45 to 65 seconds. The coffee should steadily drip into the carafe below the brewer.

steps.title: Pour enough water to measure 500 g.
steps.content: Pour enough water to measure 500 g. Take 35 to 40 seconds to slowly pour the rest of the water into the coffee grounds. Your scale should read 500 g once you've poured enough water into the brewer. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the pour over and serve the coffee.
steps.content: Remove the pour over and serve the coffee. Once the coffee has finished dripping out of the bottom, lift off the pour over brewer. Carefully pour the hot coffee into 2 mugs or cups and serve them immediately. [10] X Research source You can discard or compost your coffee grounds. Wash out the pour over brewer according to the manufacturer's instructions.
